text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: Humanitarian organizations rely more than ever on digital technologies to assist and protect people in
label: BODY

text: crisis.1 These technologies enable humanitarians to gather data to understand and respond to the needs of
label: BODY

text: affected people, and offer new channels to deliver aid through unprecedented digital proximity.2 However,
label: BODY

text: this increased digitalization is not without risks—chief among them is the growing risk of cyber threats.3
label: BODY

text: Cyber threats are one of the most pressing issues facing the humanitarian sector today.4 Digital
label: BODY

text: transformation, increasing dependence on information and communications technology (ICT), and the
label: BODY

text: prevalence of cyber threats create a new array of risks for humanitarian agencies and the people they serve.
label: BODY

text: A few examples include:
label: BODY

text: 1     NetHope (2022). Humanitarians (and data) #NotATarget.
label: BODY

text: 2    Massimo Marelli and Adrian Perrig (2020). Hacking Humanitarians: Mapping The Cyber Environment And Threat Landscape, International
label: BODY

text: Committee of the Red Cross, 7 May.
label: BODY

text: 3    UNOCHA GHPF (2022). Virtual Risk, Tangible Harm: The Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats.
label: BODY

text: 4    World Economic Forum (2022). The Global Risks Report 2022 17th Edition. Geneva.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH1

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH1

text: GUIDANCE NOTE ON THE IMPLICATIONS OF
label: HH1

text: CYBER THREATS FOR HUMANITARIANS
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH1

text: •	 Cyber threats are one of the most pressing issues facing the humanitarian sector today. Digital
label: BODY

text: transformation, increasing dependence on information and communications technology, and the
label: BODY

text: prevalence of cyber threats create a new array of risks for humanitarian agencies and the people
label: BODY

text: they serve.
label: BODY

text: •	 Cyber threats comprise a variety of activities and behaviors that can be distinguished by the
label: BODY

text: types of actors behind them and their motives, as well as the type of threat.
label: BODY

text: •	 Common vulnerabilities in the humanitarian sector include infrastructure flaws, inadequate
label: BODY

text: basic cybersecurity and digital literacy, human error and the absence of coordinated approaches.
label: BODY

text: •	 Cyber threats can compromise humanitarians’ ability to deliver assistance and protect affected
label: BODY

text: populations. They directly affect a number of key humanitarian programming areas, including
label: BODY

text: protection, access, and accountability to affected populations and communicating with
label: BODY

text: communities.
label: BODY

text: •	 In order to improve cyber resilience, organizations should invest in cybersecurity as a
label: BODY

text: cross-organizational issue, enhance institutional preparedness, increase digital literacy of staff,
label: BODY

text: and improve coordination and collaboration.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: 5     Rebecca Root (2020). COVID-19 Brings Wave of Cyberattacks Against NGOs, Devex, 13 April.
label: BODY

text: 6    World Health Organization (2020). WHO Reports Fivefold Increase in Cyberattacks, Urges Vigilance, 23 April.
label: BODY

text: 7     Kelly Sheridan (2021). US Seizes Attacker Domains Used in USAID Phishing Campaign, DARKReading, 1 June; Adva Saldinger (2021). USAID Hack is
label: BODY

text: ‘Wakeup Call’ for Aid Industry on Cybersecurity, Devex, 4 June.
label: BODY

text: 8    International Committee of the Red Cross (2022). Cyber-Attack on ICRC: What We Know, 16 February.
label: BODY

text: 9    ICRC (2022). ICRC proposes digital red cross/crescent emblem to signal protection in cyberspace, 3 November. Linked to this is the notion of the
label: BODY

text: “sovereign cloud” – i.e., a cloud architecture in which data sovereignty can be respected and applied. See ICRC (2020). Handbook on Data Protection
label: BODY

text: in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 10  ICRC (2022). The ICRC opens a new delegation for cyberspace in Luxembourg, 17 November.
label: BODY

text: 11   NetHope (2022). Digital Protection and Cybersecurity.
label: BODY

text: 12  Adapted from: International Telecommunication Union (ITU) Recommendation ITU-T X.1205, Overview of cybersecurity.
label: BODY

text: 13  IASC, 2021. Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 14  UNOCHA GHPF (2022). Virtual Risk, Tangible Harm: The Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats.
label: BODY

text: •	 In April 2020, at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, Mercy Corps and the International
label: BODY

text: Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) reported a drastic uptick in data protection
label: BODY

text: breaches,5 and the World Health Organization (WHO) noted a fivefold increase in the number of cyber
label: BODY

text: threats against the organization.6
label: BODY

text: •	 In May 2021, hackers gained access to the email marketing account of the United States Agency for
label: BODY

text: International Development (USAID), emailing over 150 organizations in an apparent attempt to hack
label: BODY

text: them.7
label: BODY

text: •	 In February 2022, a highly targeted cyber operation against servers of the International Committee
label: BODY

text: of the Red Cross (ICRC) which compromised sensitive data of more than 515,000 individuals was
label: BODY

text: detected.8
label: BODY

text: These attacks may cause serious harm. They violate the privacy of the people whose data is compromised,
label: BODY

text: risk exposing sensitive information about them and erode trust in humanitarian organizations’ capabilities.
label: BODY

text: In response to these attacks, a number of new initiatives signal increased investment in this area. For
label: BODY

text: example, ICRC is considering the development of a ‘digital emblem’9 and has also opened a new delegation
label: BODY

text: for cyberspace in Luxembourg.10 NetHope has established an Information Sharing and Analysis Center that
label: BODY

text: will help support the information security needs of nonprofit agencies and the world’s most vulnerable
label: BODY

text: communities.11 However, the sector lacks a shared approach to mitigating the risk and potential impact of
label: BODY

text: cyber threats.
label: BODY

text: This Guidance Note aims to help build a common understanding and support more strategic, collective
label: BODY

text: action within the sector. It provides an overview of the cyber threats, vulnerabilities, and implications
label: BODY

text: facing humanitarians and people affected by crises, and offers recommendations to increase cyber
label: BODY

text: resilience within and across organizations and their partners.
label: BODY

text: Definitions
label: BODY

text: Cybersecurity entails a combination of tools, policies, security concepts, security safeguards, guidelines,
label: HH1

text: risk management approaches, actions, training, best practices, assurance and technologies that can be
label: BODY

text: used to protect the cyber environment, and organization and user assets against relevant security risks in
label: BODY

text: the cyber environment.12
label: BODY

text: Information and data security entails a set of physical, technological and procedural measures that
label: HH1

text: safeguard the confidentiality, integrity and availability of data, and prevent its accidental or intentional,
label: BODY

text: unlawful or otherwise unauthorized loss, destruction, alteration, acquisition or disclosure.13
label: BODY

text: Cyber threats encompass ‘activities that occur at least in part within the cyber realm, utilizing and/or
label: HH1

text: targeting information communications technologies to achieve an effect that is not authorized by the
label: BODY

text: legitimate user of the data or the ICT and/or has a harmful intent or effect on the victim or victims’.14
label: BODY

text: Cyber resilience refers to an organization’s capacity to identify, prevent and detect cyber threats, and
label: HH1

text: respond and recover.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: 15  Denial-of-service (DoS) and Distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks flood a system’s resources, overwhelming them and preventing responses to
label: BODY

text: service requests, which reduces the system’s ability to perform. (Source: IBM).
label: BODY

text: 16  Malware is malicious software that can render infected systems inoperable. Most malware variants destroy data by deleting or wiping files critical to
label: BODY

text: the operating system’s ability to run. (Source: IBM).
label: BODY

text: 17  Ransomware is sophisticated malware that takes advantage of system weaknesses, using strong encryption to hold data or system functionality
label: BODY

text: hostage. Cybercriminals use ransomware to demand payment in exchange for releasing the system. A recent development with ransomware is the
label: BODY

text: add-on of extortion tactics. (Source: IBM).
label: BODY

text: 18  International Committee of the Red Cross (November 2019). International Humanitarian Law and the Challenges of Contemporary Armed
label: BODY

text: Conflicts: Recommitting to Protection in Armed Conflict on the 70th Anniversary of the Geneva Conventions.
label: BODY

text: 19  European Parliamentary Research Service (June 2022).  Russia’s war on Ukraine: Timeline of cyber-attacks.
label: BODY

text: 20 UN. Hate speech and real harm; Human Rights Council (2018). Report of the Independent International Fact-finding Mission on Myanmar
label: BODY

text: CYBER THREATS
label: HH1

text: To increase cybersecurity within the sector, organizations must first understand the threats they may face
label: BODY

text: in this sphere. Cyber threats comprise a wide variety of activities and behaviors that can be distinguished
label: BODY

text: by the types of actors behind them and their motives. Actors range from nation-states to criminal
label: BODY

text: organizations and private persons or combinations thereof. The affiliation and goals of actors can inform
label: BODY

text: how aggressively they behave, how sophisticated attacks are, which methods are used and who is targeted.
label: BODY

text: Cyber threats can be direct or indirect, depending on the target. Direct cyber threats, which target
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organizations, have increased in recent years. Indirect cyber threats target the infrastructure
label: BODY

text: or services that people affected by or responding to humanitarian crises rely on for survival and aid
label: BODY

text: delivery.
label: BODY

text: Cyber threats can also be classified according to their type or mode. These include Denial-of-service (DoS)
label: BODY

text: and Distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks,15 malware,16 and ransomware,17 among others.
label: BODY

text: The following examples illustrate what cyber threats might look like in practice:
label: BODY

text: •	 Cyber warfare refers to ‘operations against a computer, a computer system or network, or another
label: HH1

text: connected device, through a data stream, when used as means or methods of warfare in the context
label: BODY

text: of an armed conflict’.18 In Ukraine, cyber-attacks have undermined the distribution of medicines, food
label: BODY

text: and relief supplies since February 2022.19 Their impact has ranged from preventing access to basic
label: BODY

text: services to data theft and disinformation.
label: BODY

text: •	 Misinformation, disinformation and hate speech (MDH) refers to the organized dissemination
label: HH1

text: (intentional or unintentional) of false information through means of ICT which discredits political,
label: BODY

text: military or civil society actors, or spreads, incites, promotes or justifies hatred and violence based on
label: BODY

text: intolerance. In Myanmar, a campaign of MDH with derogatory and dehumanizing language against the
label: BODY

text: Rohingya Muslim minority of the country has been linked to the commission of grave human rights
label: BODY

text: violations.20
label: BODY

text: •	 Cybercrime refers to criminal offenses that are cyber-enabled (committed through the means of ICT)
label: HH1

text: or cyber-dependent (only possible because of ICT).
label: BODY

text: •	 Cyber sabotage refers to activities aiming to disrupt or destroy the reliable and error-free functioning
label: HH1

text: of ICT. If an act of sabotage is carried out by perpetrators with terrorist motives, it is referred to as
label: BODY

text: cyber terrorism.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: 21  UN (2021). Cybersecurity in the United Nations system organizations: Report of the Joint Inspection Unit.
label: BODY

text: 22  UN (2021). Cybersecurity in the United Nations system organizations: Report of the Joint Inspection Unit.
label: BODY

text: 23  Checkpoint (2020). Critical Infrastructure and SCADA/ICS Cybersecurity Vulnerabilities and Threats.
label: BODY

text: 24  Massimo Marelli (2021). The SolarWinds hack: lessons for humanitarians. International Committee of the Red Cross, 18 May.
label: BODY

text: 25  Between June 2020 and April 2022, the CyberPeace Institute analyzed data on 379 cyber-attacks against the healthcare sector across 36 countries
label: BODY

text: with an average of 165,000 records breached per incident—and this is a mere fraction of the full extent of the problem. In 2015, a sophisticated
label: BODY

text: malware operation targeting Ukraine’s electricity grid left 230,000 residents without power for up to six hours in the middle of winter, in the first
label: BODY

text: confirmed hack to take down a power grid. Israel’s national water provider Mekorot reported in 2021 that its water networks are subject to “several
label: BODY

text: hundreds of thousands of hacking attempts” per year. In February 2022, satellite communications firm Viasat reported a suspected cyber-attack that
label: BODY

text: resulted in a partial outage of residential broadband services in Ukraine and other European countries. Noëlle van der Waag-Cowling (2022). Living
label: BODY

text: Below the Cyber Poverty Line: Strategic Challenges for Africa, ICRC Humanitarian Law & Policy Blog, 11 June.
label: BODY

text: 26  Massimo Marelli (2021). The SolarWinds hack: lessons for humanitarians. International Committee of the Red Cross, 18 May.
label: BODY

text: 27  UN GHPF (2021). The Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats.
label: BODY

text: 28 WEF (2022). Why the humanitarian sector needs to make cybersecurity a priority, 17 January.
label: BODY

text: 29 Catherine Cheney (2022). Delivering digital aid when the internet becomes a weapon of war, DevEx, 28 January.
label: BODY

text: COMMON VULNERABILITIES IN THE HUMANITARIAN SECTOR
label: HH1

text: Humanitarian actors should investigate and understand potential vulnerabilities that might impact their
label: BODY

text: cyber resilience, and make them more susceptible to becoming victims of cyber threats. These include
label: BODY

text: infrastructure flaws, inadequate basic cybersecurity and digital literacy, human error and the absence of a
label: BODY

text: coordinated approach.
label: BODY

text: 1.	 Infrastructure flaws
label: HH1

text: Cyber threats are commonly associated with sophisticated technical operations targeting vulnerabilities
label: BODY

text: in information infrastructure.21 Common vulnerabilities of this type relevant to the humanitarian sector
label: BODY

text: include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Legacy systems: Outdated computing software and/or hardware that are unable to resist
label: HH1

text: contemporary forms of attack, and present a risk for other applications and data that may share the
label: BODY

text: same infrastructure.22
label: BODY

text: •	 Default or improper configuration: Out-of-box systems, i.e., with default or simple passwords and
label: HH1

text: overly permissive configurations are easier for attackers to compromise.23
label: BODY

text: •	 Lack of encryption: In the absence of encryption, attackers can use software to discover usernames
label: HH1

text: and passwords. A lack of encryption means that an attacker can access the data on compromised
label: BODY

text: devices. Data that is transferred via unencrypted channels is also at risk of unauthorized access.
label: BODY

text: •	 Third-party infrastructure: Attackers can infiltrate ICT systems through an outside partner or
label: HH1

text: vendor by exploiting different vulnerabilities.24 Attackers may also gain access to the data stored by
label: BODY

text: providers. Disruption of critical infrastructure through cyber operations can lead to a shutdown of
label: BODY

text: essential services, which can have grave consequences for people in need and disrupt humanitarian
label: BODY

text: operations.25 Vendor lock-in due to product incompatibilities, low levels of interoperability or
label: BODY

text: portability, or limited alternatives in the market are also major concerns.26
label: BODY

text: 2.	 Inadequate basic cybersecurity and digital literacy
label: HH1

text: Cybersecurity preparedness, organizational readiness and digital literacy remain limited in the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector.27 Inadequate data literacy, and a lack of consistent practices and tools to ensure
label: BODY

text: cybersecurity are widespread among humanitarian organizations. Cybersecurity continues to be seen as a
label: BODY

text: predominantly technical issue, leading to little engagement from staff or leadership to raise awareness of
label: BODY

text: threats and equip people across organizations with the skills and tools required to mitigate risk. This lack
label: BODY

text: of engagement and focus also translates into a lack of resources and funding for cybersecurity.28 Even as
label: BODY

text: humanitarian actors digitalize their operations, gaps remain between the investment in the front end of
label: BODY

text: technology (building it, deploying it, and closing out the project), and the back end (maintaining services
label: BODY

text: and keeping information secure and protected over time).29
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: 30 UN (2021). Cybersecurity in the United Nations system organizations: Report of the Joint Inspection Unit.
label: BODY

text: 31  WEF (2020). After reading, writing and arithmetic, the 4th ‘r’ of literacy is cyber-risk.
label: BODY

text: 32 UN (2021). Cybersecurity in the United Nations system organizations: Report of the Joint Inspection Unit.
label: BODY

text: 33 One notable example of communication about cyber breaches was the ICRC’s reaction to the 2022 cyber-attack, about which the organization
label: BODY

text: communicated in a very transparent and timely manner, keeping partners and beneficiaries informed to the best of their abilities.
label: BODY

text: 34 UNOCHA GHPF (2022). Virtual Risk, Tangible Harm: The Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats.
label: BODY

text: 35 UNOCHA on Message: Humanitarian Principles.
label: BODY

text: 36 Brittany Card. (2015). Applying Humanitarian Principles To Current Uses Of Information Communication Technologies: Gaps In Doctrine And
label: BODY

text: Challenges To Practice.Signal Program on Human Security and Technology, Harvard Humanitarian Initiative.
label: BODY

text: 3.	 Human error
label: HH1

text: There has been a discernible shift from hackers attacking servers, networks and devices to ‘hacking
label: BODY

text: people’ in recent years.30 Ninety-five percent of cybersecurity breaches are now caused by human error.31
label: BODY

text: Social engineering techniques (phishing, impersonation, etc.) aimed at manipulating individuals into
label: BODY

text: divulging sensitive information are the most prevalent means of exploiting this vulnerability. Most of these
label: BODY

text: techniques are designed to reach a high number of users simultaneously, maximizing the likelihood of a
label: BODY

text: breach. These intrusions can go undetected for extended periods of time, giving attackers access to internal
label: BODY

text: security architecture and confidential information, which in turn offers further opportunities for attack.
label: BODY

text: Human error that increases vulnerability to cyber threats may include:
label: BODY

text: •	 accidental abuse by users with authorized and legitimate access to computer systems;
label: BODY

text: •	 unauthorized use by attackers enabled by a compromised user;
label: BODY

text: •	 disregard by personnel for security policies and procedures; and
label: BODY

text: •	 errors in the configuration or operation of systems.
label: BODY

text: 4.	 Absence of coordinated approach
label: HH1

text: There is an acute gap in coordination on cyber-related issues in the humanitarian sector. This gap exists
label: BODY

text: both within and between organizations. Few organizations have teams dedicated to cybersecurity or tasked
label: BODY

text: with detecting, assessing and mitigating cyber risks. No single entity is formally tasked with coordinating
label: BODY

text: a harmonized approach to cybersecurity in the sector, despite the existence of initiatives such as the ones
label: BODY

text: described above, the development of resources and apparent political will.32
label: BODY

text: The lack of coordination means that organizations lack visibility on attacks experienced by their peers, are
label: BODY

text: unable or do not have policies in place to consistently share information on experienced cyber threats or
label: BODY

text: lessons learned, and are not investing in collective approaches to reducing vulnerabilities and mitigating
label: BODY

text: risk.33
label: BODY

text: HUMANITARIAN IMPLICATIONS OF CYBER THREATS
label: HH1

text: The humanitarian implications of cyber threats are significant. They can compromise the ability to deliver
label: BODY

text: assistance and protection, as well as exacerbate humanitarian needs by disrupting services essential
label: BODY

text: for survival. Cyber threats can result in surveillance, discrimination, persecution and other harmful
label: BODY

text: consequences for affected populations, exacerbate the insecurities of already vulnerable groups and
label: BODY

text: individuals, erode trust and compromise the principled delivery of humanitarian assistance.34
label: BODY

text: Delivering principled aid means that humanitarian services and assistance are aligned with the
label: BODY

text: principles of humanity, neutrality, impartiality and independence.35 To act with neutrality in the digital
label: BODY

text: realm, humanitarian actors ‘must ensure that the data and systems they employ do not provide any
label: BODY

text: tactical military or operational advantage to parties engaged in hostilities’.36 The humanitarian principle
label: BODY

text: of independence might be in conflict with the dependence of ICT-supported humanitarian work on
label: BODY

text: infrastructure owned and managed by private companies affiliated with different states. The overarching
label: BODY

text: principle of ‘Do No Harm’ further obliges all humanitarians to avoid exposing people to additional risks
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: 37 ALNAP (2018). Incorporating the principle of “Do No Harm”: How to take action without causing harm - Reflections on a review of Humanity &
label: BODY

text: Inclusion’s practices.
label: BODY

text: 38 UNOCHA, Themes: Protection.
label: BODY

text: 39 Sandvik, Jacobsen and McDonald (2017). Do no harm: A taxonomy of the challenges of humanitarian experimentation, International Review of the
label: BODY

text: 40 ICRC (2020). Handbook on Data Protection in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 41  ‘Incidents reported include social engineering attacks such as phishing employed via messaging apps (targeting of Tibetan diaspora via Whatsapp)
label: BODY

text: profiling and targeting of the Tibetan Diaspora through WhatsApp); commercially available spyware used against political dissidents outside of
label: BODY

text: country of origin and for targeting asylum seekers; as well as new vulnerabilities that are being regularly discovered and patched in major messaging
label: BODY

text: services (eg. Whatsapp)’ see UNHCR (2021). Using Social Media in Community Based Protection: A Guide.
label: BODY

text: 42 OCHA on Message (April 2017). Humanitarian Access.
label: BODY

text: 43  Fore more on these vulnerabilities and how they are exacerbated by emerging cyber threats, see: UNOCHA GHPF (2022). Virtual Risk, Tangible
label: BODY

text: Harm: The Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats.
label: BODY

text: 44  KeepItOn (2019). The State of Internet Shutdowns around the world. The 2018 #KeepItOn Report, Access Now for the #KeepItOn coalition.
label: BODY

text: 45  World Food Programme (WFP)/UNHCR (2014). Joint Assessment Mission: Kenya Refugee Operation, Dadaab (23–25 June 2014) and Kakuma (30
label: BODY

text: June–1 July 2014) Refugee Camps, 2014.
label: BODY

text: through humanitarian action, requiring humanitarians to take a step back from an intervention to look at
label: BODY

text: the broader context and mitigate potential negative effects.37
label: BODY

text: Cyber threats directly affect a number of key humanitarian domains, such as protection, access, and
label: BODY

text: accountability to affected people (AAP) and communicating with communities (CwC). As the technical tools
label: BODY

text: for managing data in these different areas have evolved faster than the policy instruments that govern their
label: BODY

text: use, organizations must exercise caution as they design and deploy digital technologies. The sections below
label: BODY

text: offer considerations to help organizations better understand and address the humanitarian implications of
label: BODY

text: cyber threats across these domains.
label: BODY

text: 1.	 Protection
label: HH1

text: For humanitarian organizations, protection entails advocating for and supporting actions that aim to
label: BODY

text: reduce and prevent people’s exposure to risks and to ensure respect for the rights of individuals by those
label: BODY

text: responsible.38 Humanitarians must consider how cyber threats and related vulnerabilities impact their
label: BODY

text: protection responsibilities, what effects technology might have on the distribution of resources, and how
label: BODY

text: reliance on cyber infrastructure and vendors is redefining relationships.39
label: BODY

text: Information about the location of vulnerable people, as well as data that allows for re-identification
label: BODY

text: of victims of gender-based violence are two examples of protection-specific concerns that might be
label: BODY

text: exacerbated by the use of ICT as they might render such information more easily accessible to threat
label: BODY

text: actors.40 Another protection concern is that of the protection of humanitarian data. For example, the use of
label: BODY

text: social media has become more commonplace in the delivery of services, but this brings with it a number of
label: BODY

text: significant data protection risks such as profiling.41
label: BODY

text: 2.	 Access
label: HH1

text: Humanitarian access refers to both humanitarian actors’ ability to reach populations in need and affected
label: BODY

text: populations’ ability to access assistance and services.42
label: BODY

text: The use of ICT can help increase and simplify beneficiaries’ access to humanitarian services such as cash
label: BODY

text: assistance, referral services or healthcare. The increased reliance by humanitarians on digital technologies,
label: BODY

text: and the related dependencies on external and internal infrastructure and services, can however bring new
label: BODY

text: challenges.
label: BODY

text: Access to services can be impeded by the inherent vulnerabilities of the sectors on which organizations
label: BODY

text: and beneficiaries rely (such as healthcare, logistics, banking, and more).43 The continuity of services in the
label: BODY

text: digital space is not always a given—internet shutdowns and network failures can cause major disruptions
label: BODY

text: to the provision of essential services.44 In Kenya, such a network failure led to ‘occasional delays, disruption
label: BODY

text: or cancellation of the food distribution in the camps, contributing to long queues and crowd control
label: BODY

text: challenges’.45
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: 46 IASC: Accountability to Affected Populations (AAP) : A brief overview.
label: BODY

text: 47 OCHA (2014). OCHA on Message: Communications with Communities.
label: BODY

text: 48 CDAC (2021). Digital Communication and Accountability: Insights from a year of discussions with CDAC Network.
label: BODY

text: 49 International Review of the Red Cross (2020). Q&A: Humanitarian operations, the spread of harmful information and data protection. IRRC 102 (913),
label: BODY

text: 50 UN (2021). Cybersecurity in the United Nations system organizations: Report of the Joint Inspection Unit.
label: BODY

text: 3.	 Accountability to affected people and communications with communities
label: HH1

text: Accountability to affected people is an active commitment to use power responsibly by taking account of,
label: BODY

text: giving account to, and being held to account by the people humanitarian organizations seek to assist.46
label: BODY

text: Communications with Communities aims to meet the information and communications needs of people
label: BODY

text: affected by crisis.47
label: BODY

text: Ensuring timely and reliable access to and use of information is paramount to AAP and CwC. Increasingly,
label: BODY

text: humanitarians provide this information at least in part through digital channels, either to complement
label: BODY

text: face-to-face services or where physical proximity to communities is not feasible. This dependency on digital
label: BODY

text: services means that cyber operations stand to have grave humanitarian repercussions.
label: BODY

text: One particular threat related to AAP and CwC is misinformation, disinformation and hate speech, which
label: BODY

text: has become more prevalent with the increased use of ICT.48 MDH can put affected communities and
label: BODY

text: humanitarian workers at risk by further destabilizing fragile environments, increasing vulnerability and
label: BODY

text: affecting humanitarian organizations’ reputation.49
label: BODY

text: Recommendations
label: HH1

text: Humanitarian organizations should consider the following recommendations to improve cyber resilience.
label: BODY

text: Invest in cybersecurity as a cross-organizational issue by:
label: HH1

text: •	 Integrating cybersecurity into broader organizational frameworks and strategies, including relevant
label: BODY

text: legal, technical and operational safeguards.
label: BODY

text: •	 Promoting an active stance from staff at all levels through awareness-raising programmes and
label: BODY

text: displaying an engaged leadership style on cybersecurity matters overall.50
label: BODY

text: •	 Allocating appropriate long-term and flexible funding for cybersecurity and data responsibility as an
label: BODY

text: integral component of humanitarian programming.
label: BODY

text: •	 Advocating for increased investment into the responsible operations of digital technologies to reduce
label: BODY

text: related vulnerabilities.
label: BODY

text: Enhance institutional preparedness by:
label: HH1

text: •	 Identifying and analyzing common cybersecurity challenges including identifying potential threats
label: BODY

text: and threat actors specific to their work, as well as the potential vulnerabilities in their operations and
label: BODY

text: systems.
label: BODY

text: •	 Conducting regular risk assessments to identify threats and vulnerabilities, particularly when planning
label: BODY

text: new cyber-enabled activities or exploring new technologies to support activities.
label: BODY

text: •	 Implementing several mitigation measures, such as putting in place security standards for hardware
label: BODY

text: and software, and adopting a ‘zero trust’ approach that favors restrictions such as least-privilege
label: BODY

text: access, microsegmentation and multi-factor authentication.
label: BODY

text: •	 Diversifying supply chains to remove strong supplier dependencies, and considering free and open
label: BODY

text: source alternatives (as long as they are approved or appropriately vetted).
label: BODY

text: •	 Developing and adapting existing technologies to humanitarian situations, and ensuring
label: BODY

text: contextualized tailoring, testing, efficacy and safety before deployment.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: MARCH 2023
label: BODY

text: 51  Centre for Humanitarian Data (2019). Guidance Note on Data Incident Management.
label: BODY

text: 52  Centre for Humanitarian Data (2022). Guidance Note on Data Security in Operational Data Management.
label: BODY

text: 53  Centre for Humanitarian Data (2020). Guidance Note on Data Responsibility in Public-Private Partnerships.
label: BODY

text: 54  UNOCHA GHPF (2022). Virtual Risk, Tangible Harm: The Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats.
label: BODY

text: •	 Establishing internal and cross-organizational approaches to identifying, resolving, tracking and
label: BODY

text: communicating about data incidents.51
label: BODY

text: Increase digital literacy of staff by:
label: HH1

text: •	 Dedicating appropriate resources and funding for training and awareness raising efforts.
label: BODY

text: •	 Engaging and training staff and stakeholders regularly to help build cybersecurity into everyday
label: BODY

text: working practices.
label: BODY

text: •	 Building digital literacy of humanitarian actors through cross-sector hires and upskilling.
label: BODY

text: •	 Increasing data literacy to enable staff to adopt responsible practices and improve their cyber hygiene,
label: BODY

text: including practicing good password management, using anti-virus/anti-malware software and
label: BODY

text: avoiding phishing scams.52
label: BODY

text: Improve coordination and collaboration by:
label: HH1

text: •	 Creating an environment that fosters a culture of coordination, collaboration and information sharing
label: BODY

text: among actors.
label: BODY

text: •	 Integrating into wider public and private sector cybersecurity communities, ensuring they participate
label: BODY

text: in threat intelligence analysis and information-sharing channels, including disclosure.
label: BODY

text: •	 Partnering with relevant stakeholders to improve cybersecurity and humanitarians’ access to new
label: BODY

text: areas of expertise and technologies.53
label: BODY

text: •	 Supporting existing initiatives, systems and projects, for example promoting interoperable data
label: BODY

text: sharing platforms with adequate protections for personal and sensitive data within and across
label: BODY

text: organizations and sectors.
label: BODY

text: •	 Communicating about initiatives, threat scanning and  potential breaches to highlight the issue of
label: BODY

text: cybersecurity and support the development of a knowledge base, fostering a more coordinated
label: BODY

text: approach to incident management over time.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’), together with key partners, is publishing a set of guidance
label: BODY

text: notes and tip sheets on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2022 and 2023. These
label: BODY

text: complement the Centre’s series of guidance notes and tip sheets, as well as the Inter-Agency Standing
label: BODY

text: Committee Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action and the OCHA Data
label: BODY

text: Responsibility Guidelines, which were published in February 2021 and October 2021 respectively. Through the
label: BODY

text: series, the Centre aims to support continued engagement from different stakeholder groups around high-level
label: BODY

text: commitments and collective action on data responsibility. These guidance notes have been made possible with
label: BODY

text: the support of the Government of Switzerland.
label: BODY

text: This Guidance Note on the Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats builds on OCHA’s publications on cyber
label: BODY

text: related issues in the humanitarian sector, including Humanitarianism in the Age of Cyber-warfare: Towards the
label: BODY

text: Principled and Secure Use of Information in Humanitarian Emergencies and the 2022 Overview Paper on Virtual
label: BODY

text: Risk, Tangible Harm: The Humanitarian Implications of Cyber Threats.54
label: BODY
